column4: Hello all! Do we have any certified linux gurus online at this time?
Because I have a *hard* question :-)

I've got a *very* old linux binary I wish to run under ubuntu 6.06. Under Red Hat (a couple of years ago) all I had to do was install libc 5 (including libm 5) and version 1 of the dynamic runtime linker.
I tried this under ubuntu, and the executable just seg faults straight away.
I tried running ldd on the binary, and *that* seg faulted.
you can't install glibc in ubuntu, for some reason, ubuntu doesn't like it when you try
Why not? Is it a kernel problem?
no, glibc is statically linked, you can't change it
That's doesn't sound like it relates to my problem. The kernel should load the runtime linker to load my binary - glibc shouldn't get involved at all.
I thought you said you wanted to replace glibc
I've installed libc5 already on my machine
The problem is, even with the old libc5 and ld-linux1 I get a seg fault as soon as I try to run the binary.
ldd seg faults when trying to list the dependancies of the binary.
do the libc's conflict?
I can't see how. They should install side by side as they have different names and versions
just asking
might I ask what you're trying to run?
The fraunhofer mp3 encoder from circa 1997. I've encoded all my music with it for the last 8 years and wish to continue to do so.
LAME *cough*
Why it doesn't want to run it the issue I'm interested in.
Yes, but I don't want to use LAME. I'm happy with the fraunhofer one.
Are there any resources on running old binaries under ubuntu? Like I said, this worked on fedora core, ooo, 2 I think, just fine.
dunno...
